Sub_topics.description: Know that plant and animal cells are eukaryotic and have a cell membrane, cytoplasm and genetic material enclosed in a nucleus. Know that bacterial cells are prokaryotic, much smaller, have cytoplasm and a cell membrane surrounded by a cell wall; genetic material is not enclosed in a nucleus and is a single DNA loop; bacteria may also contain one or more plasmids (small rings of DNA).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cell size, scale and standard form
Sub_topics.description: Be able to demonstrate understanding of the scale and size of cells and make order of magnitude calculations, including using standard form. Use prefixes centi (c), milli (m), micro (µ) and nano (n) appropriately in size/scale contexts.

Be able to explain how the main sub-cellular structures in animal cells relate to their functions, including: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria and ribosomes (function-structure relationships).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plant cell organelles and functions (incl chloroplasts)
Sub_topics.description: Be able to explain how the main sub-cellular structures in plant cells relate to their functions, including: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes, chloroplasts and a permanent vacuole with cell sap. Know that plant and algal cells have a cellulose cell wall that strengthens the cell.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Estimating relative size/area of sub-cellular structures
Sub_topics.description: Be able to use estimations and explain when they should be used to judge the relative size or area of sub-cellular structures (eg comparing organelles on micrographs/images).

Required practical activity 1: use a light microscope to observe, draw and label a selection of plant and animal cells; include an appropriate magnification scale. Skills include producing labelled biological drawings and using microscopy; apply estimation of relative size/area of sub-cellular structures where appropriate.

Given appropriate information, be able to explain how the structure of different types of cell relates to their function in a tissue, organ, organ system or organism. Required examples: in animals—sperm cells, nerve cells, muscle cells; in plants—root hair cells, xylem cells, phloem cells.

Explain the importance of cell differentiation. Know that as an organism develops, cells differentiate to form different types of cells; most animal cells differentiate early, whereas many plant cells retain the ability to differentiate throughout life. Know that in mature animals, cell division is mainly for repair and replacement; as a cell differentiates it acquires different sub-cellular structures to carry out a particular function and becomes specialised.

Understand how microscopy techniques have developed over time and explain how electron microscopy has increased understanding of sub-cellular structures. Limited to differences in magnification and resolution: electron microscopes have much higher magnification and resolving power than light microscopes, enabling finer detail of cells and more sub-cellular structures to be seen and understood.

Carry out calculations involving magnification, real size and image size using: magnification = size of image / size of real object. Express answers in standard form when appropriate; use unit prefixes (centi, milli, micro, nano) correctly.

(Biology only) Know that bacteria multiply by binary fission as often as every 20 minutes with sufficient nutrients and suitable temperature. Know that bacteria can be grown in nutrient broth or as colonies on an agar gel plate. Understand that uncontaminated cultures are required to investigate disinfectants/antibiotics.

(Biology only) Describe how to prepare an uncontaminated culture using aseptic technique and explain why: Petri dishes and culture media must be sterilised before use; inoculating loops must be sterilised by passing through a flame; lids should be secured with adhesive tape and plates stored upside down; in school labs cultures should generally be incubated at 25°C (to reduce risk of harmful pathogen growth).
(Biology only) Calculate the number of bacteria in a population after a certain time if given the mean division time (binary fission).
(Biology only) Calculate cross-sectional areas of bacterial colonies or clear zones of inhibition using πr² (including interpreting radius/diameter measurements).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bacterial population calculations in standard form
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Express bacterial population calculations in standard form where required.

Required practical activity 2 (Biology only): investigate the effect of antiseptics or antibiotics on bacterial growth using agar plates and measuring zones of inhibition; interpret measurements and compare treatments/concentrations; apply aseptic and safe handling procedures; may involve selecting best antibiotic/concentration from data.
Know that the nucleus contains chromosomes made of DNA molecules; each chromosome carries a large number of genes. Know that in body cells chromosomes are normally found in pairs.

Describe the stages of the cell cycle including mitosis: during the cycle genetic material is doubled and then divided into two identical cells. Before division the cell grows and increases sub-cellular structures (eg ribosomes, mitochondria) and DNA replicates to form two copies of each chromosome.

Describe mitosis as part of the cell cycle: one set of chromosomes is pulled to each end, the nucleus divides, then cytoplasm and membranes divide to form two genetically identical cells. Know that detailed phases of mitosis are not required, only the three overall stages of the cell cycle.

Explain that mitosis is important for growth and development of multicellular organisms. Recognise and describe situations (given contexts) where mitosis is occurring (eg growth, repair, replacement).
Define a stem cell as an undifferentiated cell capable of giving rise to many more cells of the same type and (via differentiation) to certain other cell types.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cells in embryos, adults and plants
Sub_topics.description: Describe the function of stem cells in: human embryos (can differentiate into most different types of human cells); adult bone marrow (can form many types including blood cells); plant meristems (can differentiate into any type of plant cell throughout the plant’s life). Knowledge and understanding of stem cell techniques are not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cells in medicine: potential benefits
Sub_topics.description: Explain that treatment with stem cells may help conditions such as diabetes and paralysis; understand basic idea of using stem cells to repair damaged tissues/organs by growing new tissue.
Describe therapeutic cloning: an embryo is produced with the same genes as the patient; stem cells from the embryo are not rejected and may be used for medical treatment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stem cells: risks and ethical/religious objections
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate that stem cells have potential risks (eg transfer of viral infection) and that some people have ethical or religious objections to their use in medical research/treatments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plant stem cells for cloning crops and conservation
Sub_topics.description: Explain that stem cells from plant meristems can be used to produce clones quickly and economically; applications include cloning rare species to protect from extinction and cloning crop plants with special features (eg disease resistance) to produce large numbers of identical plants.

Explain diffusion as the spreading out of particles of a substance in solution or gas, resulting in net movement from higher concentration to lower concentration (down a concentration gradient). Explain that substances move into and out of cells by diffusion across cell membranes.
Apply diffusion to examples: oxygen and carbon dioxide in gas exchange; urea as a waste product diffusing from cells into blood plasma for excretion in the kidneys.
Explain how rate of diffusion is affected by: difference in concentrations (concentration gradient), temperature, and surface area of the membrane.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Surface area to volume ratio in single-celled organisms
Sub_topics.description: Explain that a single-celled organism has a relatively large surface area to volume ratio, allowing sufficient transport of molecules into and out of the cell to meet needs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculating surface area to volume ratio
Sub_topics.description: Calculate and compare surface area to volume ratios (including interpreting what a larger/smaller ratio implies for exchange).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Need for exchange surfaces and transport systems
Sub_topics.description: Explain the need for exchange surfaces and transport systems in multicellular organisms in terms of surface area to volume ratio limitations.

Explain how exchange surfaces are adapted for efficient exchange: large surface area, thin membrane (short diffusion path), (in animals) efficient blood supply, and (for gaseous exchange in animals) ventilation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exchange surfaces examples (lungs, gills, roots, leaves, intestine)
Sub_topics.description: Explain (given context) how the small intestine and lungs in mammals, gills in fish, and roots and leaves in plants are adapted for exchanging materials using the key features of effective exchange surfaces.
Define osmosis as the diffusion of water from a dilute solution to a concentrated solution through a partially permeable membrane; explain that water moves across cell membranes by osmosis.
Use simple compound measures of rate of water uptake; use percentages; calculate percentage gain and loss of mass of plant tissue in osmosis investigations.
Plot, draw and interpret appropriate graphs for osmosis practical data (eg concentration vs mass change/percentage change).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: osmosis in plant tissue (RP3)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 3: investigate effect of a range of concentrations of salt or sugar solutions on mass of plant tissue; measure mass change, calculate percentage change, and present/interpret data graphically.
Define active transport as movement of substances from a more dilute solution to a more concentrated solution (against a concentration gradient), requiring energy from respiration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Active transport in plants: mineral ion uptake
Sub_topics.description: Explain how active transport allows mineral ions to be absorbed into plant root hair cells from very dilute solutions in the soil; know that plants require ions for healthy growth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Active transport in humans: glucose uptake in gut
Sub_topics.description: Explain how active transport allows sugar molecules (eg glucose) to be absorbed from lower concentrations in the gut into the blood which has a higher sugar concentration; relate to use of sugars in respiration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Compare diffusion, osmosis and active transport
Sub_topics.description: Describe how substances are transported into and out of cells by diffusion, osmosis and active transport; explain the differences between the three processes (direction relative to concentration gradient; substance moved; energy requirement; membrane properties).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Levels of organisation: cell to organism
Sub_topics.description: Define and apply principles of organisation: cells are basic building blocks; a tissue is a group of cells with similar structure and function; organs are aggregations of tissues performing specific functions; organs are organised into organ systems that work together to form organisms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Digestive system as an organ system (overview)
Sub_topics.description: Know that the digestive system is an organ system in which several organs work together to digest and absorb food; apply understanding that digestion produces soluble molecules for absorption into the bloodstream.
Describe enzymes as molecules that catalyse specific reactions in living organisms due to the shape of their active site; relate enzyme specificity to the active site.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enzyme activity affected by temperature and pH
Sub_topics.description: Describe the nature of enzyme molecules and relate enzyme activity to temperature and pH changes (including that enzymes have optimum conditions and activity changes when conditions change).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lock and key model of enzyme action
Sub_topics.description: Use the ‘lock and key theory’ as a simplified model to explain enzyme action; be able to use other models in explanation if provided.
Recall that amylase (a carbohydrase) is produced in the salivary glands, pancreas and small intestine and breaks down starch (a carbohydrate) into simple sugars.
Recall that proteases are produced in the stomach, pancreas and small intestine and break down proteins into amino acids.
Recall that lipases are produced in the pancreas and small intestine and break down lipids (fats) into glycerol and fatty acids.

Explain that digestive enzymes convert food into small soluble molecules that can be absorbed into the bloodstream; explain that products of digestion are used to build new carbohydrates, lipids and proteins and that some glucose is used in respiration.

Describe bile as made in the liver and stored in the gall bladder; explain that bile is alkaline to neutralise hydrochloric acid from the stomach; explain that bile emulsifies fat into small droplets increasing surface area; explain why alkaline conditions and increased surface area increase the rate of fat breakdown by lipase.

Required practical activity 4: use qualitative reagents to test for carbohydrates, lipids and proteins, including Benedict’s test for sugars, iodine test for starch, and Biuret reagent for protein; interpret colour changes as positive/negative results.

Required practical activity 5: investigate effect of pH on rate of amylase reaction using continuous sampling; determine time to completely digest starch at a range of pH values; use iodine to test for starch every 30 seconds; control temperature using water bath/electric heater; interpret results as rate/time comparisons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heart structure and double circulatory system
Sub_topics.description: Describe the heart as an organ that pumps blood around the body in a double circulatory system: right ventricle pumps blood to lungs for gas exchange; left ventricle pumps blood to the rest of the body.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Major blood vessels of the heart (names)
Sub_topics.description: Recall the blood vessels associated with the heart: aorta, vena cava, pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein and coronary arteries. Names of heart valves are not required.

Recall lung structure limited to trachea, bronchi, alveoli and the capillary network surrounding the alveoli; relate lungs being adapted for gaseous exchange to alveoli/capillaries (thin walls, large area, blood supply, ventilation).

Explain that resting heart rate is controlled by a group of cells in the right atrium acting as a natural pacemaker; describe artificial pacemakers as electrical devices used to correct irregularities in heart rate.
Describe the three types of blood vessel (arteries, veins, capillaries) and explain how their structures relate to their functions (eg wall thickness, lumen size, valves, pressure, exchange).
Use simple compound measures such as rate and carry out rate calculations for blood flow when given data (eg volume per time).

Describe blood as a tissue consisting of plasma with red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets suspended; know the function of each component (plasma transport; red blood cells oxygen transport; white blood cells defence; platelets clotting).

Recognise different types of blood cells from photographs/diagrams and explain how each is adapted to its function (eg red blood cells biconcave/no nucleus for oxygen transport; white blood cells for immune response; platelets for clotting).
Describe CHD as layers of fatty material building up in coronary arteries, narrowing them and reducing blood flow to heart muscle, causing lack of oxygen.
Explain use of stents to keep coronary arteries open; evaluate advantages and disadvantages of this mechanical device treatment in context.
Explain that statins reduce blood cholesterol levels and slow the rate of fatty material deposition; evaluate advantages and disadvantages of using drugs to treat cardiovascular disease.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Faulty heart valves: consequences and replacement
Sub_topics.description: Understand consequences of faulty heart valves (not opening fully or leaking) on blood flow; describe that valves can be replaced using biological or mechanical valves; evaluate pros/cons in context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heart failure: transplants and artificial hearts
Sub_topics.description: Describe treatment options for heart failure: heart or heart-and-lung transplant from donor; artificial hearts used temporarily while waiting for transplant or to allow heart to rest; evaluate advantages/disadvantages of transplant vs mechanical devices.

Define health as physical and mental well-being. Explain that communicable and non-communicable diseases cause ill health and that other factors (diet, stress, life situations) affect physical and mental health. Explain interactions between different diseases, including: immune system defects increase infectious disease risk; viruses in cells can trigger cancers; immune reactions can trigger allergies (eg rashes, asthma); severe physical ill health can lead to depression and other mental illness.

Explain that risk factors are linked to increased rate of disease and can be lifestyle aspects or substances in body/environment. Understand that causal mechanisms are proven for some risk factors but not others; many diseases result from interaction of multiple factors.
Explain effects of diet, smoking and exercise on cardiovascular disease incidence (including interpreting data about these risk factors).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lifestyle factors: obesity and Type 2 diabetes
Sub_topics.description: Explain obesity as a risk factor for Type 2 diabetes; interpret data about correlation vs causation where relevant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lifestyle factors: alcohol effects on liver and brain
Sub_topics.description: Explain the effect of alcohol on the liver and brain function as non-communicable disease risk/health impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lifestyle factors: smoking, lung disease and lung cancer
Sub_topics.description: Explain effect of smoking on lung disease and lung cancer; interpret data about smoking as a risk factor.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Smoking and alcohol effects on unborn babies
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of smoking and alcohol on unborn babies (eg development/health risks) as part of lifestyle risk factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Carcinogens and ionising radiation as cancer risks
Sub_topics.description: Explain carcinogens, including ionising radiation, as risk factors in cancer.
Discuss human and financial costs of non-communicable diseases to individuals, communities, nations, and globally; link to prevention via lifestyle changes.

Describe cancer as result of changes in cells leading to uncontrolled growth and division. Distinguish benign tumours (abnormal cell growth contained in one area, usually within a membrane; do not invade/spread) from malignant tumours (cancers that invade neighbouring tissues and spread via blood to form secondary tumours).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cancer risk factors: lifestyle and genetic
Sub_topics.description: Explain that scientists have identified lifestyle risk factors for various cancers and that some cancers have genetic risk factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plant tissues and leaf structure (named tissues)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how structures of plant tissues are related to their functions. Know plant tissues include: epidermal tissue, palisade mesophyll, spongy mesophyll, xylem, phloem, meristem tissue (growing tips). Know leaf structure limited to: epidermis, palisade/spongy mesophyll, xylem and phloem, guard cells and stomata.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Root hair cells: adaptations for water and ions
Sub_topics.description: Explain how root hair cells are adapted for efficient uptake of water by osmosis and mineral ions by active transport (large surface area, thin cell wall, etc).
Describe xylem tissue as hollow tubes strengthened by lignin; explain adaptation for transporting water and mineral ions from roots to stems/leaves in the transpiration stream.

Describe phloem tissue transporting dissolved sugars from leaves to rest of plant for immediate use or storage; define movement through phloem as translocation. Know phloem consists of tubes of elongated cells; cell sap moves between phloem cells through pores in end walls. Detailed phloem structure/mechanism of transport not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stomata and guard cells: role in gas exchange and water loss
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of stomata and guard cells in controlling gas exchange and water loss (opening/closing stomata to regulate transpiration and CO₂ uptake).
Describe process of transpiration (water evaporating from leaf surfaces and diffusing out through stomata, pulling water up xylem as a transpiration stream).

Explain effect of changing temperature, humidity, air movement (wind) and light intensity on rate of transpiration, using appropriate biological reasoning (eg stomatal opening, evaporation rate, diffusion gradient).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Transpiration rate as a compound measure
Sub_topics.description: Understand and use simple compound measures such as rate of transpiration (eg volume/time, distance/time in potometer readings) and interpret results from tables/graphs.

Explain how diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, protists and fungi are spread in animals and plants. Know pathogens are microorganisms that cause infectious disease and can be spread by direct contact, by water or by air; pathogens may infect plants or animals.
Explain how the spread of communicable diseases can be reduced or prevented (eg hygiene, isolation, vaccination, controlling vectors, safe sex, clean water/food; apply to contexts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bacteria vs viruses in the body
Sub_topics.description: Know that bacteria and viruses may reproduce rapidly inside the body. Know that bacteria may produce toxins (poisons) that damage tissues and make us feel ill. Know that viruses live and reproduce inside cells causing cell damage.

Describe measles as a viral disease with symptoms of fever and red skin rash; understand it can be serious/fatal if complications arise; explain why vaccination is used. Know measles virus is spread by inhalation of droplets from sneezes/coughs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: HIV/AIDS: stages, immune impact, transmission, treatment idea
Sub_topics.description: Describe HIV initially causing flu-like illness; explain that without successful control by antiretroviral drugs it attacks immune cells; late stage infection (AIDS) occurs when immune system is badly damaged and cannot deal with other infections/cancers. Know HIV is spread by sexual contact or exchange of body fluids such as blood (eg sharing needles).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) effects on plants
Sub_topics.description: Describe TMV as a widespread plant viral pathogen (eg tomatoes) causing a mosaic pattern of leaf discolouration; explain that it reduces photosynthesis and affects plant growth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Salmonella food poisoning: spread and symptoms; control by vaccination
Sub_topics.description: Describe Salmonella food poisoning as bacterial disease spread by bacteria ingested in food or due to unhygienic preparation. Know symptoms include fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting and diarrhoea caused by bacteria and toxins. Know poultry may be vaccinated in the UK to control spread.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gonorrhoea: symptoms, spread, antibiotic resistance, control
Sub_topics.description: Describe gonorrhoea as an STD with thick yellow/green discharge and pain on urinating; caused by a bacterium. Know it was treated with penicillin but resistant strains appeared. Explain spread by sexual contact and control by antibiotics and barrier contraception (condoms).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rose black spot: symptoms, spread and treatment
Sub_topics.description: Describe rose black spot as a fungal disease causing purple/black leaf spots; leaves may turn yellow and drop early; reduces photosynthesis and growth. Know it is spread by water or wind and treated using fungicides and/or removing and destroying affected leaves.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Malaria: protist life cycle with mosquito vector and control
Sub_topics.description: Describe malaria as caused by protist pathogens with a life cycle including the mosquito vector; causes recurrent fever and can be fatal. Explain control by preventing mosquito breeding (vector control) and using mosquito nets to avoid bites.
Describe non-specific defence systems of the human body against pathogens including: skin; nose; trachea and bronchi; stomach (eg acid).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Immune system role and white blood cell actions
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of immune system in defence: if a pathogen enters body, immune system tries to destroy it. Describe how white blood cells defend by phagocytosis, antibody production and antitoxin production.

Explain how vaccination prevents illness: introducing small quantities of dead/inactive pathogen stimulates white blood cells to produce antibodies; upon re-exposure white blood cells respond quickly producing correct antibodies preventing infection. No need for specific schedules/side effects details.
Explain how spread of pathogens can be reduced by immunising a large proportion of the population (herd immunity concept).
Explain use of antibiotics (eg penicillin) to cure bacterial disease by killing infective bacteria; understand importance of treating specific bacteria with specific antibiotics.
Explain that antibiotic use has reduced deaths from bacterial diseases but emergence of antibiotic-resistant strains is a major concern; link to why treatments may fail.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Antibiotics do not treat viral infections
Sub_topics.description: Explain why antibiotics cannot kill viral pathogens (viruses live inside cells; antibiotics target bacterial processes).
Explain that painkillers and other medicines treat symptoms but do not kill pathogens; explain that developing drugs that kill viruses without damaging body tissues is difficult.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drug discovery: traditional sources and examples
Sub_topics.description: Describe traditional drug sources from plants/microorganisms and recall examples: digitalis from foxgloves (heart drug), aspirin from willow (painkiller), penicillin discovered from Penicillium mould by Alexander Fleming.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drug development: synthesis and starting points
Sub_topics.description: Know most new drugs are synthesised by chemists in pharmaceutical industry, though starting points may still be chemicals extracted from plants.
Describe preclinical testing of new drugs for toxicity, efficacy and dose using cells, tissues and live animals in a laboratory.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Clinical trials: volunteers, patients, low dose to optimum dose
Sub_topics.description: Describe clinical trials using healthy volunteers and patients: start with very low doses; if safe, conduct further trials to find optimum dose.
Explain double blind trials: some patients receive placebo; neither patient nor doctor knows who receives drug/placebo during trial to reduce bias.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monoclonal antibodies: specificity and production method
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) as produced from a single clone of cells; specific to one binding site on one protein antigen so they target specific chemicals/cells. Describe production: stimulate mouse lymphocytes to make a particular antibody; combine lymphocytes with tumour cells to form hybridoma; hybridoma divides and makes antibody; clone single hybridoma cells to make many identical antibody-producing cells; collect and purify large amounts of antibody.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monoclonal antibodies: diagnosis and measurement uses
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe uses of monoclonal antibodies including diagnosis (eg pregnancy tests) and laboratory measurement of hormone/chemical levels in blood or detection of pathogens. Students need not recall specific named tests; given information should explain how they work via binding to antigens.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monoclonal antibodies: locating molecules with fluorescent dyes
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe use of monoclonal antibodies in research to locate/identify specific molecules in cells/tissues by binding to them with a fluorescent dye.

(Biology only) Explain how monoclonal antibodies can treat cancer: antibody bound to radioactive substance/toxic drug/chemical that stops cell growth; delivers treatment to cancer cells without harming other body cells (target specificity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monoclonal antibodies: side effects and evaluation
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that monoclonal antibodies can create more side effects than expected and are not as widely used as originally hoped; evaluate advantages and disadvantages of their use in diagnosis/treatment.
(Biology only) Detect plant diseases by symptoms including: stunted growth; spots on leaves; areas of decay (rot); growths; malformed stems/leaves; discolouration; presence of pests.
(Biology only) Identify plant diseases by: reference to a gardening manual/website; taking infected plants to a lab to identify pathogen; using testing kits containing monoclonal antibodies.

(Biology only) Know plants can be infected by viral, bacterial and fungal pathogens and by insects. Knowledge restricted to: tobacco mosaic virus (viral), black spot (fungal), and aphids (insects/pests).
(Biology only) Describe stunted growth caused by nitrate ion deficiency; know nitrate ions are needed for protein synthesis and therefore growth.
(Biology only) Describe chlorosis (yellowing of leaves) caused by magnesium ion deficiency; know magnesium ions are needed to make chlorophyll.

(Biology only) Describe physical plant defence responses to resist invasion of microorganisms: cellulose cell walls; tough waxy cuticle on leaves; layers of dead cells around stems (bark) that fall off.
(Biology only) Describe chemical plant defence responses: antibacterial chemicals; poisons to deter herbivores.
(Biology only) Describe mechanical adaptations that deter herbivores: thorns and hairs; leaves droop/curl when touched; mimicry to trick animals.
Know the photosynthesis equation: carbon dioxide + water → glucose + oxygen (in the presence of light). Recognise chemical symbols CO₂, H₂O, O₂ and C₆H₁₂O₆.
Describe photosynthesis as an endothermic reaction in which energy is transferred from the environment to chloroplasts by light.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting rate of photosynthesis (single factor)
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of temperature, light intensity, carbon dioxide concentration and amount of chlorophyll on rate of photosynthesis; interpret graphs of rate involving one limiting factor.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Measuring and calculating rate of photosynthesis
Sub_topics.description: Measure and calculate rates of photosynthesis from experimental data (eg oxygen bubbles/volume per unit time), translate between numeric and graphical form, and plot/draw appropriate graphs with suitable axis scales.
Explain that factors interact and any one may limit photosynthesis; interpret graphs involving two or three factors and decide which is the limiting factor.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inverse square law and light intensity
Sub_topics.description: Understand and use inverse proportion (inverse square law) for light intensity in the context of photosynthesis (eg intensity ∝ 1/d²).
Apply limiting factors to greenhouse economics: relate data about limiting factors to cost-effectiveness of adding heat, light or carbon dioxide to maximise photosynthesis while maintaining profit.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: light intensity and photosynthesis (RP6)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 6: investigate effect of light intensity on rate of photosynthesis using an aquatic organism (eg pondweed). Measure oxygen production rate, control temperature (heat shield/water bath), collect repeat data at each intensity, plot and interpret rate vs light intensity graphs; Higher tier may apply inverse square law.
Explain that glucose produced in photosynthesis can be used for respiration (energy release in cells).
Explain that glucose can be converted into insoluble starch for storage in plants.
Explain that glucose can be used to produce fat or oil for storage in plants.
Explain that glucose can be used to produce cellulose which strengthens the plant cell wall.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Glucose + nitrate ions for amino acids/proteins
Sub_topics.description: Explain that glucose is used to produce amino acids for protein synthesis and that plants also require nitrate ions absorbed from soil to make amino acids/proteins.
Describe cellular respiration as an exothermic reaction continuously occurring in living cells; explain that energy transferred supplies energy needed for living processes.
Explain that organisms need energy for: chemical reactions to build larger molecules; movement; keeping warm (thermoregulation).
Know aerobic respiration equation: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water. Recognise symbols C₆H₁₂O₆, O₂, CO₂, H₂O.
Know anaerobic respiration in muscles: glucose → lactic acid. Explain that incomplete oxidation transfers much less energy than aerobic respiration.

Know anaerobic respiration in plant and yeast cells: glucose → ethanol + carbon dioxide. Know anaerobic respiration in yeast is fermentation and has economic importance in bread and alcoholic drinks manufacture.
Compare aerobic and anaerobic respiration regarding: need for oxygen, products formed, and relative amounts of energy transferred (aerobic more, anaerobic less).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exercise response: heart rate and ventilation changes
Sub_topics.description: Describe body response to exercise: increased energy demand causes heart rate, breathing rate and breath volume to increase to supply muscles with more oxygenated blood.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lactic acid, oxygen debt and fatigue
Sub_topics.description: Explain that if insufficient oxygen is supplied, anaerobic respiration occurs in muscles; lactic acid builds up causing fatigue and creating oxygen debt. Define oxygen debt as extra oxygen needed after exercise to react with and remove accumulated lactic acid from cells.
Explain that blood transports lactic acid to the liver where it is converted back into glucose (role of liver in recovery from anaerobic respiration).
Define metabolism as the sum of all the reactions in a cell or the body; understand metabolism is enzyme-controlled and uses energy transferred by respiration to synthesise new molecules.
Explain metabolism includes conversion of glucose to starch, glycogen and cellulose (storage/structural carbohydrates).
Explain formation of lipid molecules from one glycerol molecule and three fatty acids (building lipids).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metabolism examples: amino acids and proteins (plants)
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of glucose and nitrate ions to form amino acids which are used to synthesise proteins (link to plant mineral nutrition).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metabolism examples: respiration and urea formation
Sub_topics.description: Explain metabolism includes respiration and breakdown of excess proteins to form urea for excretion.

Explain homeostasis as regulation of internal conditions of a cell/organism to maintain optimum conditions for function in response to internal and external changes; relate to maintaining optimal conditions for enzyme action and cell functions.
Know that homeostasis in the human body includes control of blood glucose concentration, body temperature, and water levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Control system components: receptors, coordination centres, effectors
Sub_topics.description: Describe that all control systems include: receptors detecting stimuli, coordination centres (eg brain, spinal cord, pancreas) receiving/processing information, and effectors (muscles or glands) bringing about responses to restore optimum levels; understand responses can be nervous or chemical.

Explain how nervous system enables humans to react and coordinate behaviour; describe that information from receptors travels along neurones as electrical impulses to CNS (brain and spinal cord), which coordinates responses of effectors (muscles contracting or glands secreting hormones).

Explain how structures in a reflex arc relate to function, including sensory neurone, synapse, relay neurone and motor neurone; explain why reflex actions are important (rapid, automatic, protective).
Explain that reflex actions are automatic and rapid and do not involve the conscious part of the brain.
Extract and interpret data from graphs/charts/tables about nervous system functioning; translate reaction time information between numerical and graphical forms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: factors affecting reaction time (RP7)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 7: plan and carry out an investigation into the effect of a factor on human reaction time; measure time accurately, collect sufficient data, present results (including graphs where appropriate) and interpret trends/patterns.
(Biology only) Identify cerebral cortex, cerebellum and medulla on a brain diagram and describe their functions (control of complex behaviour; coordination; control of unconscious activities).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Investigating brain function: difficulties and methods
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain difficulties of investigating brain function and treating brain damage/disease; know mapping has used studies of brain-damaged patients, electrical stimulation and MRI scanning; complexity and delicacy make investigation/treatment difficult.
(Biology only) Relate eye structures to functions; identify and explain structure-function for: retina, optic nerve, sclera, cornea, iris, ciliary muscles, suspensory ligaments.
(Biology only) Explain accommodation for near objects: ciliary muscles contract; suspensory ligaments loosen; lens becomes thicker and refracts light more strongly.
(Biology only) Explain accommodation for distant objects: ciliary muscles relax; suspensory ligaments tighten; lens becomes thinner and refracts light less strongly.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Myopia and hyperopia; lens correction and treatments
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain myopia (short sight) and hyperopia (long sight) as failure of light rays to focus on retina; explain correction using spectacle lenses that refract rays to focus on retina; know other technologies include hard/soft contact lenses, laser surgery altering cornea shape, and replacement lens in eye.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interpreting ray diagrams for eye defects and correction
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Interpret ray diagrams showing myopia/hyperopia and demonstrate how spectacle lenses correct them.

(Biology only) Describe that body temperature is monitored and controlled by thermoregulatory centre in brain; receptors in centre are sensitive to blood temperature; skin contains temperature receptors and sends impulses to centre.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thermoregulation when too hot: vasodilation and sweating
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe responses when body temperature too high: blood vessels dilate (vasodilation) and sweat produced by sweat glands; both increase transfer of energy from skin to environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thermoregulation when too cold: vasoconstriction and shivering
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe responses when body temperature too low: blood vessels constrict (vasoconstriction), sweating stops, skeletal muscles contract (shiver). Explain how these mechanisms raise/lower body temperature in context.

Describe hormonal coordination and control by endocrine system: glands secrete hormones into bloodstream; blood carries hormone to target organ to produce effect; compared with nervous system, effects are slower but longer-lasting. Know pituitary gland is a ‘master gland’ releasing hormones that act on other glands. Identify positions of pituitary gland, pancreas, thyroid, adrenal gland, ovaries and testes on a body diagram.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Insulin control of blood glucose (high glucose)
Sub_topics.description: Explain blood glucose is monitored/controlled by pancreas. If glucose too high, pancreas produces insulin causing glucose to move from blood into cells; in liver and muscle, excess glucose converted to glycogen for storage.
Compare and describe Type 1 diabetes as pancreas failing to produce sufficient insulin, causing uncontrolled high blood glucose; treated with insulin injections.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Type 2 diabetes: cause, risk factor and treatment
Sub_topics.description: Compare and describe Type 2 diabetes as body cells no longer responding to insulin; common treatments include carbohydrate-controlled diet and exercise; obesity is a risk factor.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Blood glucose graphs and insulin effect
Sub_topics.description: Extract information and interpret data from graphs showing effect of insulin on blood glucose levels in people with and without diabetes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Glucagon and negative feedback control of blood glucose
Sub_topics.description: Explain that if blood glucose too low, pancreas produces glucagon causing glycogen to convert to glucose and be released into blood; explain how glucagon interacts with insulin in a negative feedback cycle to control blood glucose.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Water loss routes and lack of control (lungs/skin)
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe that water leaves body via lungs during exhalation and water/ions/urea are lost in sweat from skin; there is no control over these losses by lungs or skin.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kidneys and urine: removal of excess water/ions/urea
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that excess water, ions and urea are removed by kidneys in urine; explain that if cells gain/lose too much water by osmosis they function inefficiently.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deamination and urea formation in liver
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that digestion of proteins can result in excess amino acids; in liver amino acids are deaminated to form ammonia; ammonia is toxic and is immediately converted to urea for safe excretion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kidney function: filtration and selective reabsorption
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe kidneys producing urine by filtration of blood and selective reabsorption of useful substances (glucose, some ions, water). Knowledge of urinary system parts, kidney structure or nephron structure is not required.
(Biology only) Describe effect of ADH on permeability of kidney tubules: released by pituitary when blood too concentrated; increases water reabsorption into blood; controlled by negative feedback.
(Biology only) Describe basic principles of kidney dialysis used in kidney failure; compare treatment by dialysis vs organ transplant including advantages/disadvantages.
Describe that during puberty reproductive hormones cause secondary sex characteristics to develop.
Describe oestrogen as main female reproductive hormone produced in ovaries; at puberty eggs begin to mature and one is released approximately every 28 days (ovulation).
Describe testosterone as main male reproductive hormone produced by testes; stimulates sperm production.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Menstrual cycle hormones: FSH and LH roles
Sub_topics.description: Describe roles: follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) causes maturation of an egg in ovary; luteinising hormone (LH) stimulates release of egg.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Menstrual cycle hormones: oestrogen and progesterone roles
Sub_topics.description: Describe that oestrogen and progesterone are involved in maintaining the uterus lining during the menstrual cycle.
Explain interactions of FSH, oestrogen, LH and progesterone in control of the menstrual cycle; interpret graphs of hormone levels through the cycle.
Evaluate contraception methods. Describe oral contraceptives containing hormones that inhibit FSH production so that no eggs mature.
Describe injection, implant or skin patch of slow-release progesterone to inhibit maturation and release of eggs for months/years.
Describe barrier methods such as condoms and diaphragms preventing sperm reaching an egg.
Describe intrauterine devices preventing implantation of an embryo and/or releasing a hormone.
Describe spermicidal agents that kill or disable sperm.
Describe abstaining from intercourse when an egg may be in the oviduct as a method of contraception.
Describe surgical methods of male and female sterilisation as non-hormonal contraception.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fertility treatment with FSH and LH
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of hormones to treat infertility: giving FSH and LH as a fertility drug to stimulate egg maturation/ovulation so pregnancy may occur normally.

Explain IVF: give mother FSH and LH to stimulate maturation of several eggs; collect eggs and fertilise with sperm in lab; embryos develop; at tiny ball-of-cells stage, one or two embryos inserted into uterus. Evaluate IVF including stress, low success rates, and risk of multiple births to mother/babies.
Explain adrenaline is produced by adrenal glands during fear/stress; increases heart rate and boosts delivery of oxygen and glucose to brain and muscles to prepare for ‘fight or flight’.

Explain thyroxine from thyroid gland stimulates basal metabolic rate and is important for growth/development; explain that thyroxine levels are controlled by negative feedback (interpret simple negative feedback diagrams).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plant hormones: auxin distribution and tropisms
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that plants produce hormones to coordinate and control growth and responses to light (phototropism) and gravity (gravitropism/geotropism). Explain that unequal distributions of auxin cause unequal growth rates in roots and shoots (directional growth responses).
(Biology only) Know gibberellins are important in initiating seed germination and ethene controls cell division and ripening of fruits; mechanisms of how they work are not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: seedlings response to light/gravity (RP8)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 8 (Biology only): investigate effect of light or gravity on growth of newly germinated seedlings; record results as length measurements and careful labelled biological drawings showing effects; interpret directional growth responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using auxins: weed killers, rooting powders, tissue culture
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe uses of auxins in agriculture/horticulture: as selective weed killers; as rooting powders; to promote growth in tissue culture.
(Biology only) Describe use of ethene in food industry to control ripening of fruit during storage and transport.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using gibberellins: dormancy, flowering, fruit size
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe uses of gibberellins: end seed dormancy, promote flowering, increase fruit size.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sexual reproduction: gamete fusion and variation
Sub_topics.description: Describe sexual reproduction as fusion of male and female gametes (sperm and egg in animals; pollen and egg in flowering plants). Explain that sexual reproduction involves mixing of genetic information leading to variation in offspring; gametes are formed by meiosis.
Describe asexual reproduction as involving one parent with no fusion of gametes and no mixing of genetic information, producing genetically identical offspring (clones); only mitosis is involved.
Understand that meiosis produces non-identical cells whereas mitosis produces identical cells; apply this to reproduction contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Meiosis halves chromosome number; fertilisation restores diploid
Sub_topics.description: Explain how meiosis halves the number of chromosomes in gametes and fertilisation restores the full number of chromosomes; after fertilisation, new cell divides by mitosis, cell number increases, and cells differentiate as embryo develops. Detailed stages of meiosis not required.

(Biology only) Explain advantages of sexual reproduction: produces variation; if environment changes, variation gives survival advantage by natural selection; selective breeding can speed up natural selection to increase food production.

(Biology only) Explain advantages of asexual reproduction: only one parent needed; more time/energy efficient (no mate needed); faster than sexual reproduction; many identical offspring can be produced when conditions are favourable.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Organisms using both sexual and asexual reproduction
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Know that some organisms reproduce by both methods depending on circumstances; restricted examples: malarial parasites asexually in human host and sexually in mosquito; many fungi asexually by spores and also sexually; many plants produce seeds sexually but also asexually by runners (strawberries) or bulb division (daffodils). Be able to explain pros/cons for any organism given information.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: DNA structure and chromosomes (double helix polymer)
Sub_topics.description: Describe DNA as genetic material in nucleus; DNA is a polymer of two strands forming a double helix; DNA is contained in chromosomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gene definition and protein coding idea
Sub_topics.description: Define a gene as a small section of DNA on a chromosome; explain that each gene codes for a particular sequence of amino acids to make a specific protein.

Define genome as the entire genetic material of an organism. Discuss importance of understanding human genome limited to: searching for genes linked to diseases; understanding/treating inherited disorders; tracing human migration patterns from the past.

(Biology only) Describe DNA as a polymer made from four different nucleotides; each nucleotide has a common sugar and phosphate group and one of four bases (A, C, G, T) attached to the sugar. Describe DNA strands as alternating sugar-phosphate backbone with bases attached; DNA polymer consists of repeating nucleotide units.
(Biology only) Explain that a sequence of three bases codes for a particular amino acid; order of bases controls order of amino acids assembled to produce a particular protein.
(Biology only) Describe complementary base pairing: C pairs with G and T pairs with A in complementary strands.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protein synthesis (simple) and DNA to protein link
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Recall a simple description of protein synthesis: proteins are synthesised on ribosomes using a template; carrier molecules bring specific amino acids in correct order; completed chain folds into unique shape enabling function (eg enzymes, hormones, structural proteins like collagen). Students are not expected to know mRNA/tRNA structures or detailed amino acid/protein structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic variants and phenotype: coding vs non-coding DNA
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that genetic variants may influence phenotype by: (a) coding DNA changes altering the activity of a protein; (b) non-coding DNA variations altering how genes are expressed (switching genes on/off).

(Biology only) Explain mutations occur continuously: most do not alter protein or only slightly; a few cause altered proteins with different shapes, affecting enzyme-substrate fit or structural protein strength. Explain how a change in DNA structure can change the protein synthesised by a gene.
Explain terms: gamete, chromosome, gene, allele, dominant, recessive, homozygous, heterozygous, genotype, phenotype; apply correctly in genetic contexts.

Know that some characteristics are controlled by a single gene (examples: fur colour in mice; red-green colour blindness in humans). Explain that genes can have different forms called alleles; genotype operates at molecular level to produce phenotype.
Explain dominant allele is expressed even if only one copy present; recessive allele expressed only if two copies present (no dominant allele).
Explain that organisms are homozygous if two alleles are the same for a trait and heterozygous if alleles differ.
Recall that most characteristics are the result of multiple genes interacting (polygenic inheritance) rather than single-gene control.

Complete Punnett square diagrams and extract/interpret information from genetic crosses; understand probability in predicting outcomes of single-gene crosses; use direct proportion and simple ratios to express outcomes.
Construct genetic crosses using Punnett square diagrams and make predictions using probability theory (including expected genotype/phenotype ratios).
Extract and interpret information from family trees/pedigrees to determine inheritance patterns and possible genotypes in single-gene traits.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inherited disorders: polydactyly and cystic fibrosis
Sub_topics.description: Describe inherited disorders as caused by inheritance of certain alleles. Know examples: polydactyly caused by a dominant allele; cystic fibrosis (a disorder of cell membranes) caused by a recessive allele.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Embryo screening: social, ethical and economic issues
Sub_topics.description: Make informed judgements about economic, social and ethical issues concerning embryo screening (given appropriate information), including potential to alleviate suffering and ethical concerns.
Know ordinary human body cells have 23 pairs of chromosomes; 22 pairs control characteristics, one pair determines sex. Females are XX; males are XY.
Carry out a genetic cross using sex chromosomes to show sex inheritance; use direct proportion and simple ratios in outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Variation: genetic, environmental, and combined causes
Sub_topics.description: Describe variation as differences in characteristics within a population; explain variation may be due to inherited genes (genetic causes), conditions of development (environmental causes), or combination of genes and environment (genome–environment interaction influencing phenotype).

State there is usually extensive genetic variation within a population. Recall all variants arise from mutations and that most mutations have no effect on phenotype, some influence phenotype, and very few determine phenotype.
Explain that mutations occur continuously and very rarely produce a new phenotype; if suited to an environmental change, this can lead to relatively rapid change in the species.

Describe evolution as change in inherited characteristics of a population over time through natural selection, potentially resulting in new species; know theory states all species evolved from simple life forms over three billion years ago.
Explain evolution occurs through natural selection of variants giving phenotypes best suited to environment (differential survival and reproduction; passing on advantageous alleles).
Explain that if two populations of one species become so different in phenotype that they can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring, they have formed two new species (speciation outcome).

Explain selective breeding (artificial selection) as humans breeding plants/animals for desired genetic characteristics: select parents with desired trait, breed, select offspring with desired trait, repeat over many generations until all offspring show trait.
Apply selective breeding to examples: disease resistance in food crops; animals producing more meat or milk; domestic dogs with gentle nature; large/unusual flowers.
Explain that selective breeding can lead to inbreeding, making some breeds prone to disease or inherited defects; evaluate benefits and risks including ethical issues given context.

Describe genetic engineering as modifying an organism’s genome by introducing a gene from another organism to give a desired characteristic. Examples: GM crops resistant to disease or producing bigger/better fruits; GM bacteria producing human insulin to treat diabetes.

Explain potential benefits of GM crops (eg resistance to insect attack/herbicides, increased yields, improved nutritional value) and risks/concerns including impacts on populations of wild flowers/insects and that effects of eating GM crops on human health may not be fully explored; recognise that some people have objections.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic modification to treat inherited disorders (idea)
Sub_topics.description: Explain that modern medical research is exploring genetic modification to overcome some inherited disorders (conceptual understanding; no detailed techniques required at this level beyond main steps for Higher).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic engineering main steps (enzymes, vectors, insertion)
Sub_topics.description: Describe main steps in genetic engineering: enzymes isolate required gene; gene inserted into a vector (usually bacterial plasmid or virus); vector used to insert gene into required cells; genes transferred to animal/plant/microorganism cells at early development so organism develops desired characteristics.
(Biology only) Describe tissue culture as using small groups of plant cells to grow identical new plants; importance for preserving rare species and commercial nurseries.
(Biology only) Describe cuttings as a simple method to produce many identical plants from a parent plant.
(Biology only) Describe embryo transplants: splitting cells from a developing embryo before they become specialised and transplanting identical embryos into host mothers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cloning animals: adult cell cloning process
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe adult cell cloning: remove nucleus from unfertilised egg cell; insert nucleus from adult body cell (eg skin) into egg; electric shock stimulates division to form embryo; embryo cells have same genetic information as adult cell; insert ball of embryo cells into womb to continue development.
(Biology only) Explain potential benefits and risks of cloning in agriculture and medicine; recognise ethical objections (evaluation based on context).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection (steps)
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe Darwin’s theory: individuals show variation; those best suited are more likely to survive and breed; advantageous characteristics are passed to next generation. Know Darwin published On the Origin of Species (1859) and it was controversial.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Darwin’s theory was accepted gradually
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain why theory was gradually accepted: it challenged idea that God made all animals/plants; insufficient evidence at time; mechanism of inheritance/variation not known until ~50 years later.

(Biology only) Describe that Lamarck proposed inheritance of acquired characteristics (changes during lifetime passed on). Explain that we now know in the vast majority of cases this cannot occur. Study of creationism is not required.

(Biology only) Describe work of Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace in development of natural selection theory and impact on biology; know Wallace independently proposed theory, published joint writings with Darwin (1858) prompting Darwin’s 1859 publication; Wallace gathered worldwide evidence and worked on warning colouration and speciation ideas.

(Biology only) Describe steps that give rise to new species (speciation process) based on modern understanding (eg isolation, different selection pressures, genetic differences accumulate, reproductive isolation).

(Biology only) Describe development of understanding of genetics: Mendel’s breeding experiments and idea that inheritance is determined by ‘units’ passed on unchanged; explain why his work was not recognised until after his death.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chromosomes, genes and DNA: timeline to gene theory
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe how observations of chromosome behaviour during cell division led to linking Mendel’s units to chromosomes; mid-20th century DNA structure determined and gene function mechanism worked out; scientific work led to gene theory development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for evolution: fossils and antibiotic resistance
Sub_topics.description: Describe evidence for evolution including fossil record and antibiotic resistance in bacteria; understand natural selection theory is widely accepted and supported by genetic inheritance evidence and observed resistance evolution.

Describe fossils as remains of organisms from millions of years ago found in rocks; explain fossils can form when parts do not decay because decay conditions absent; when parts are replaced by minerals as they decay; or as preserved traces (footprints, burrows, rootlet traces).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Incomplete fossil record (soft-bodied organisms and geology)
Sub_topics.description: Explain why the fossil record is incomplete: many early life forms were soft-bodied leaving few traces; traces destroyed by geological activity; therefore scientists are uncertain about how life began on Earth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using fossils to infer evolutionary change
Sub_topics.description: Explain that fossils show how much or little organisms have changed as life developed on Earth; extract and interpret information from charts/graphs/tables such as evolutionary trees.

Define extinction as when no individuals of a species remain alive; describe factors contributing to extinction (eg environmental change, new predators/diseases, competition, habitat destruction, human impacts, catastrophic events).

Explain that bacteria evolve rapidly due to fast reproduction; mutations produce new strains; resistant strains survive antibiotic treatment, reproduce, increase in population and spread. Know MRSA is resistant to antibiotics.

Explain ways to reduce development of antibiotic resistance: doctors avoid inappropriate prescribing (eg for non-serious or viral infections); patients complete antibiotic courses; restrict agricultural use of antibiotics. Explain that developing new antibiotics is costly and slow and may not keep up with new resistant strains.

Describe traditional classification by Linnaeus based on structure/characteristics; know hierarchy: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species; explain binomial naming system (genus + species). Use given information to show understanding of Linnaean system.

Describe impact of biological developments on classification: improved microscopy and biochemical understanding led to new models. Describe three-domain system by Carl Woese based on chemical analysis: archaea (primitive bacteria in extreme environments), bacteria (true bacteria), eukaryota (protists, fungi, plants, animals).
Interpret evolutionary trees as showing how scientists believe organisms are related using current classification data and fossil data for extinct organisms.
Describe levels of organisation in an ecosystem from individual organism to population to community to ecosystem; apply these terms in ecological contexts.

Explain importance of interdependence and competition in a community: species depend on others for food, shelter, pollination, seed dispersal etc; removal of one species can affect whole community. Define a stable community as one where species and environmental factors are in balance so population sizes remain fairly constant.

Explain organisms compete for resources: plants compete for light, space, water and mineral ions; animals compete for food, mates and territory; given information, suggest what organisms are competing for in a habitat.
Given appropriate information, suggest how organisms are adapted to conditions in which they live. Explain adaptations as features enabling survival; can be structural, behavioural or functional.

Explain how change in an abiotic factor affects a community (given data/context). Abiotic factors include: light intensity, temperature, moisture levels, soil pH and mineral content, wind intensity/direction, carbon dioxide levels for plants, oxygen levels for aquatic animals.

Explain how change in a biotic factor affects a community (given data/context). Biotic factors include: availability of food, new predators arriving, new pathogens, one species outcompeting another so numbers are no longer sufficient to breed.
Describe extremophiles as organisms living in very extreme environments (high temperature/pressure/salt concentration); example: bacteria living in deep sea vents.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Producers and photosynthesis as biomass source
Sub_topics.description: Explain that photosynthetic organisms (producers) are the producers of biomass for life on Earth; all food chains begin with a producer (usually green plant or alga) that makes glucose by photosynthesis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Food chains and trophic positions (consumer levels)
Sub_topics.description: Describe feeding relationships as food chains: producers eaten by primary consumers, then secondary and tertiary consumers; define predators (kill/eat other animals) and prey (eaten).
Explain that in a stable community predator and prey numbers rise and fall in cycles; interpret graphs used to model predator-prey cycles.

Describe that ecologists use experimental methods including transects and quadrats to determine distribution and abundance of species; choose/describe appropriate approach given a habitat and question.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ecological data: mean, mode, median; arithmetic mean
Sub_topics.description: In ecological abundance contexts, understand and use mean, mode and median; calculate arithmetic means from sample data and choose appropriate scales for graphs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: sampling population size and distribution (RP9)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 9: measure population size of a common species in a habitat; use sampling to investigate effect of a factor on distribution (eg along a transect). Apply sampling principles, take repeats, estimate population size from quadrat counts, and present data in graphs/tables; interpret how factor affects distribution.

Recall that many different materials cycle through abiotic and biotic components of an ecosystem; explain importance of carbon and water cycles to living organisms (as sources of carbon for organic molecules and fresh water supply).
Explain carbon cycle: returns carbon from organisms to atmosphere as CO₂ via respiration (including decomposers); CO₂ taken up by plants in photosynthesis; interpret/explain carbon cycle diagrams.
Explain water cycle: provides fresh water for organisms on land; water evaporates and precipitates continuously; interpret/explain water cycle diagrams.
Explain role of microorganisms (decomposers) in cycling materials: returning carbon to atmosphere as CO₂ and mineral ions to soil through decomposition.
(Biology only) Explain how temperature, water availability and oxygen availability affect rate of decay/decomposition of biological material.
(Biology only) Calculate rate changes in decay of biological material; translate between numerical and graphical forms; plot/draw appropriate graphs with suitable scales.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Compost and biogas (methane from anaerobic decay)
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that gardeners/farmers provide optimum conditions for rapid decay to produce compost as natural fertiliser. Explain anaerobic decay produces methane; biogas generators can produce methane as a fuel.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: milk decay and pH vs temperature (RP10)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical activity 10 (Biology only): investigate effect of temperature on rate of decay of fresh milk by measuring pH change over time; present/interpret pH data and compare rates at different temperatures; evaluate method and suggest improvements.

(Biology only) Evaluate impact of environmental changes on distribution of species in an ecosystem given information. Changes include temperature, water availability, and atmospheric gas composition; changes may be seasonal, geographic or due to human interaction.

Define biodiversity as the variety of different species on Earth or within an ecosystem. Explain that high biodiversity increases ecosystem stability by reducing dependence of one species on another and maintaining the physical environment; relate to importance for human future.

Explain that human population growth and rising living standards increase resource use and waste; pollution occurs in water (sewage, fertiliser, toxic chemicals), air (smoke, acidic gases), and land (landfill, toxic chemicals). Explain pollution can kill plants/animals and reduce biodiversity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Land use change and peat bog destruction
Sub_topics.description: Explain that humans reduce land for other organisms by building, quarrying, farming and dumping waste. Explain that destruction of peat bogs to produce compost reduces habitat area and biodiversity; decay/burning of peat releases CO₂.

Describe large-scale deforestation in tropical areas to provide land for cattle/rice fields and to grow crops for biofuels; evaluate environmental implications (habitat loss, biodiversity reduction, carbon cycle impacts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Global warming gases and biological consequences
Sub_topics.description: Explain that levels of CO₂ and methane are increasing and contribute to global warming; describe some biological consequences of global warming (eg habitat shifts, distribution changes, extinction risk).

Describe programmes to reduce negative human impacts and maintain biodiversity, including: breeding programmes for endangered species; protection/regeneration of rare habitats; reintroduction of field margins and hedgerows; reduction of deforestation and CO₂ emissions; recycling resources instead of landfill. Explain impacts of positive and negative human interactions on ecosystems.

(Biology only) Describe trophic levels as numbered positions in food chains: Level 1 producers (plants/algae), Level 2 primary consumers (herbivores), Level 3 secondary consumers (carnivores eating herbivores), Level 4 tertiary consumers (carnivores eating carnivores); apex predators have no predators. Describe decomposers breaking down dead matter by secreting enzymes; soluble molecules diffuse into microorganism.
(Biology only) Describe and construct pyramids of biomass to represent relative amounts of biomass at each trophic level, with level 1 at base; construct accurate pyramids from data.

(Biology only) Explain biomass loss between trophic levels: producers transfer about 1% of incident light energy for photosynthesis; only ~10% of biomass transfers to the next trophic level. Losses due to not all ingested material absorbed (egested as faeces), and absorbed material lost as waste (CO₂ and water from respiration; water and urea in urine). Large amounts of glucose used in respiration.
(Biology only) Calculate efficiency of biomass transfers between trophic levels using percentages or fractions of mass; explain how efficiency affects numbers of organisms at each trophic level.

(Biology only) Define food security as having enough food to feed a population. Describe biological factors threatening food security: increasing birth rate; changing diets in developed countries leading to global transport of scarce resources; new pests/pathogens affecting farming; environmental changes affecting production (eg famine if rains fail); cost of agricultural inputs; conflicts affecting availability of water/food. Explain need for sustainable methods to feed all people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Improving efficiency in food production (energy transfer)
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain that efficiency of food production can be improved by restricting energy transfer from animals to environment by limiting movement and controlling temperature of surroundings; explain feeding high-protein foods to increase growth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sustainable fisheries: net size and quotas
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain fish stocks are declining and must be maintained for breeding; describe how controlling net size and introducing fishing quotas conserve stocks at sustainable levels; evaluate different fishing techniques in context.

(Biology only) Describe culturing microorganisms for food: Fusarium fungus grown aerobically on glucose syrup; biomass harvested and purified to produce mycoprotein (protein-rich food for vegetarians).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Biotechnology: GM bacteria producing human insulin
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Describe genetically modified bacteria producing human insulin; harvested and purified insulin used to treat diabetes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Biotechnology: GM crops and enhanced nutrition (golden rice)
Sub_topics.description: (Biology only) Explain how GM crops could provide more food or improved nutritional value, including example of golden rice.
Apply the key idea that life processes depend on molecules whose structure is related to their function (eg enzymes, hormones, structural proteins, DNA).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cells, tissues, organs and systems as adapted units
Sub_topics.description: Apply the key idea that cells are fundamental units of living organisms and may be part of highly adapted structures including tissues, organs and organ systems enabling living processes to be performed effectively.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Organisation beyond the organism: populations, communities, ecosystems
Sub_topics.description: Apply the key idea that living organisms form populations, communities and ecosystems that interact with each other, the environment and humans in many ways.
Apply the key idea that living organisms are interdependent and show adaptations to their environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Photosynthesis as basis of life on Earth
Sub_topics.description: Apply the key idea that life on Earth depends on photosynthesis in which green plants and algae trap light to fix carbon dioxide and combine it with hydrogen from water to make organic compounds and oxygen.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Respiration provides energy for life processes
Sub_topics.description: Apply the key idea that organic compounds are used as fuels in cellular respiration to allow other chemical reactions necessary for life.
Apply the key idea that chemicals in ecosystems are continually cycling through the natural world (eg carbon and water cycles; role of decomposers).
Apply the key idea that characteristics of an organism are influenced by its genome and its interaction with the environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Natural selection explains biodiversity and relatedness
Sub_topics.description: Apply the key idea that evolution occurs by natural selection and accounts for biodiversity and varying degrees of relatedness among organisms.
